history.content:
Highly advise doing against this. I've taken all three classes in question, here are my thoughts:

  • CS 162: a project-heavy course with a near-constant workload. Very frequently, projects, homeworks, and midterms will all fall around the same time, meaning you have to be REALLY on top of planning your time to make it work. When going into the class, it's a good idea to have your group already picked out -- you should be able to work well with your team, otherwise your life will be significantly harder. Pretty doable if it's your only intense tech, but...
  • EECS 151: the single hardest, most intense project I've ever completed for a class. In the last 6-7 weeks of the semester, the project accounts for ~30 hours a week, and if you're taking anything else with a large project (like 162) it's going to be really rough.
  • EECS 149: not especially difficult compared to the other two, but it also has a final project that can take 15-20 hours per week (varies, since it's an independent project).

Even two of these would be a hell of a semester; all three is beyond painful. Is there a reason you're trying to fit them into the same semester?

children.subject: As I said, I'd be cautious even taking two of the above, but if you do decide to do that, I'd recommend one of them be 149. It's a little lighter as far as I remember, while 151/162 were the two most intense classes (though also the most worthwhile) I've ever taken. Doable, and these are all excellent choices (I can speak less to 149, since it's changed substantially since I took it, but mostly for the better from what I've heard).
What are the best classes to take (if any) for EECS 149?

It's good to have taken CS 61C before EECS 149, because almost all the programming in the class is in C and the conceptual topics mostly relate to finite state machines, which are introduced in CS 61C as well.
Other than that, 149 is a very self-contained course

Appreciate the response Dinesh (in the student answer). Not particularly, just trying to figure out what to take next semester. In that case, I may just take some easy class and two of the above mentioned, but thanks for the insight. I've been looking for perhaps easier upper-div techs to take in the future or classes to pair with some of the harder upper-divs, since I'm just trying to take as many of the upper-divs that interest me as I can.

For sure. I ended up taking only 149 out of the three this semester concurrently with CS164 (also with an easier class tacked on). I decided to try and give myself a "light"-er semester to make sure I had time outside of classes to do other things, like recruiting as a junior. It's a pretty different schedule from what I was thinking about doing above and, I'm thinking, probably significantly easier. I'll probably be taking 162 next semester paired with either 152 or 151...
Anon, can I ask what classes you ended up taking this semester and how you're finding the workload? I'm considering taking similar classes next semester.

history.content:
Is it possible to take EECS 151 (and I suppose the lab component), EECS 149 and CS162 next semester (without any other classes).

Context--I've heard 162 is a very project heavy course, would 151 and 149 be too much on top of it? I'm hoping to take 162 early since I've also heard it's important. Also seems like 151, 149, and 162 have a lot of overlap material. The direction I'm headed in is embedded systems so I'm also hoping to take courses that closely follow 61C material. Suggestions are also appreciated

Thanks!
history.subject: EECS Fall work load (EECS151, 149, CS162)
